message.content: okay, the website landing page and blog  is deployed, add link to readme, somewhere on top https://4gray.github.io/iptvnator/

content.text: I'll add the website link to the README at the top. Let me first read the README to see the current structure.

content.content:
1‚Üí# IPTVnator - IPTV Player Application 2‚Üí 3‚Üí

4‚Üí 5‚Üí

6‚Üí

7‚Üí 8‚Üí 9‚Üí 10‚Üí

11‚Üí 12‚ÜíTelegram channel for discussions | Buy me a coffee | GitHub Sponsors 13‚Üí 14‚Üí**IPTVnator** is a video player application that provides support for IPTV playlist playback (m3u, m3u8). The application allows users to import playlists using remote URLs or by uploading files from the local file system. Additionally, it supports EPG information in XMLTV format which can be provided via URL. 15‚Üí 16‚ÜíThe application is a cross-platform, open-source project built with Electron and Angular. 17‚Üí 18‚Üí‚ö†Ô∏è Note: IPTVnator does not provide any playlists or other digital content. The channels and pictures in the screenshots are for demonstration purposes only. 19‚Üí 20‚Üí![IPTVnator: Channels list, player and epg list](./iptv-dark-theme.png) 21‚Üí 22‚Üí## Features 23‚Üí 24‚Üí- M3u and M3u8 playlist support üì∫ 25‚Üí- Xtream Code (XC) and Stalker portal (STB) support 26‚Üí- External player support - MPV, VLC 27‚Üí- Add playlists from the file system or remote URLs üìÇ 28‚Üí- Automatic playlist updates on application startup 29‚Üí- Channel search functionality üîç 30‚Üí- EPG support (TV Guide) with detailed information 31‚Üí- TV archive/catchup/timeshift functionality 32‚Üí- Group-based channel list 33‚Üí- Favorite channels management 34‚Üí- Global favorites aggregated from all playlists 35‚Üí- HTML video player with HLS.js support or Video.js-based player 36‚Üí- Internationalization with support for 16 languages: 37‚Üí * Arabic 38‚Üí * Moroccan arabic 39‚Üí * English 40‚Üí * Russian 41‚Üí * German 42‚Üí * Korean 43‚Üí * Spanish 44‚Üí * Chinese 45‚Üí * Traditional chinese 46‚Üí * French 47‚Üí * Italian 48‚Üí * Turkish 49‚Üí * Japanese 50‚Üí * Dutch 51‚Üí * Belarusian 52‚Üí * Polish 53‚Üí- Custom "User Agent" header configuration for playlists 54‚Üí- Light and Dark themes 55‚Üí- Docker version available for self-hosting 56‚Üí 57‚Üí## Screenshots: 58‚Üí 59‚Üí| Welcome screen: Playlists overview | Main player interface with channels sidebar and video player | 60‚Üí| :----------------------------------------------------------------: | :-----------------------------------------------------------: | 61‚Üí| ![Welcome screen: Playlists overview](./playlists.png) | ![Sidebar with channel and video player](./iptv-main.png) | 62‚Üí| Welcome screen: Add playlist via file upload | Welcome screen: Add playlist via URL | 63‚Üí| ![Welcome screen: Add playlist via file upload](./iptv-upload.png) | ![Welcome screen: Add playlist via URL](./upload-via-url.png) | 64‚Üí| EPG Sidebar: TV guide on the right side | General application settings | 65‚Üí| ![EPG: TV guide on the right side](./iptv-epg.png) | ![General app settings](./iptv-settings.png) | 66‚Üí| Playlist settings | 67‚Üí| ![Playlist settings](./iptv-playlist-settings.png) | | 68‚Üí 69‚Üí_Note: First version of the application which was developed as a PWA is available in an extra git branch._ 70‚Üí 71‚Üí## Download 72‚Üí 73‚ÜíDownload the latest version of the application for macOS, Windows, and Linux from the [release page](https://github.com/4gray/iptvnator/releases). 74‚Üí 75‚ÜíAlternatively, you can install the application using one of the following package managers: 76‚Üí 77‚Üí### Homebrew 78‚Üí 79‚Üí```shell 80‚Üí$ brew install iptvnator 81‚Üí``` 82‚Üí 83‚Üí### Snap 84‚Üí 85‚Üí```shell 86‚Üí$ sudo snap install iptvnator 87‚Üí``` 88‚Üí 89‚Üí### Arch 90‚Üí 91‚ÜíAlso available as an Arch PKG, [iptvnator-bin](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/iptvnator-bin/), in the AUR (using your favourite AUR-helper, .e.g. `yay`) 92‚Üí 93‚Üí```shell 94‚Üí$ yay -S iptvnator-bin 95‚Üí``` 96‚Üí 97‚Üí### Gentoo 98‚Üí 99‚ÜíYou can install IPTVnator from the [gentoo-zh overlay](https://github.com/microcai/gentoo-zh) 100‚Üí 101‚Üí```shell 102‚Üísudo eselect repository enable gentoo-zh 103‚Üísudo emerge --sync gentoo-zh 104‚Üísudo emerge iptvnator-bin 105‚Üí``` 106‚Üí 107‚Üí[![Get it from the Snap Store](https://snapcraft.io/static/images/badges/en/snap-store-black.svg)](https://snapcraft.io/iptvnator) 108‚Üí 109‚Üí 110‚Üí 111‚Üí## Troubleshooting 112‚Üí 113‚Üí### macOS: "App is damaged and can't be opened" 114‚Üí 115‚ÜíDue to Apple's Gatekeeper security and code signing requirements, you may need to remove the quarantine flag from the downloaded application: 116‚Üí 117‚Üí```bash 118‚Üíxattr -c /Applications/IPTVnator.app 119‚Üí``` 120‚Üí 121‚ÜíAlternatively, if the app is located in a different directory: 122‚Üí 123‚Üí```bash 124‚Üíxattr -c ~/Downloads/IPTVnator.app 125‚Üí``` 126‚Üí 127‚Üí### Linux: chrome-sandbox Issues 128‚Üí 129‚ÜíIf you encounter the following error when launching IPTVnator: 130‚Üí 131‚Üí``` 132‚ÜíThe SUID sandbox helper binary was found, but is not configured correctly. 133‚ÜíRather than run without sandboxing I'm aborting now. 134‚ÜíYou need to make sure that chrome-sandbox is owned by root and has mode 4755. 135‚Üí``` 136‚Üí 137‚Üí**Solution 1: Fix chrome-sandbox permissions (Recommended for .deb/.rpm installations)** 138‚Üí 139‚ÜíNavigate to the IPTVnator installation directory and run: 140‚Üí 141‚Üí```bash 142‚Üísudo chown root:root chrome-sandbox 143‚Üísudo chmod 4755 chrome-sandbox 144‚Üí``` 145‚Üí 146‚Üí**Solution 2: Launch with --no-sandbox flag** 147‚Üí 148‚ÜíEdit the desktop launcher file to add the `--no-sandbox` flag: 149‚Üí 150‚Üí1. Find your desktop file location: 151‚Üí - **Ubuntu/Debian**: `~/.local/share/applications/iptvnator.desktop` 152‚Üí - **System-wide**: `/usr/share/applications/iptvnator.desktop` 153‚Üí 154‚Üí2. Edit the file and modify the `Exec` line: 155‚Üí 156‚Üí ``` 157‚Üí Exec=iptvnator --no-sandbox %U 158‚Üí ``` 159‚Üí 160‚Üí3. Save the file and relaunch the application from your application menu. 161‚Üí 162‚ÜíAlternatively, you can launch IPTVnator from the terminal with the flag: 163‚Üí 164‚Üí```bash 165‚Üíiptvnator --no-sandbox 166‚Üí``` 167‚Üí 168‚Üí## How to Build and Develop 169‚Üí 170‚ÜíRequirements: 171‚Üí 172‚Üí- Node.js with npm 173‚Üí 174‚Üí1. Clone this repository and install project dependencies: 175‚Üí 176‚Üí ``` 177‚Üí $ npm install 178‚Üí ``` 179‚Üí 180‚Üí2. Start the application: 181‚Üí ``` 182‚Üí $ npm run serve:backend 183‚Üí ``` 184‚Üí 185‚ÜíThis will open the Electron app in a separate window, while the Angular dev server will run at http://localhost:4200. 186‚Üí 187‚ÜíTo run only the Angular app without Electron, use: 188‚Üí 189‚Üí``` 190‚Üí$ npm run serve:frontend 191‚Üí``` 192‚Üí 193‚Üí## Disclaimer 194‚Üí 195‚Üí**IPTVnator doesn't provide any playlists or other digital content.** 196‚Üí 197‚Üí 198‚Üí 199‚Üí[![All Contributors](https://img.shields.io/badge/all_contributors-13-orange.svg?style=flat-square)](#contributors) 200‚Üí 201‚Üí 202‚Üí Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

file.content:
# IPTVnator - IPTV Player Application

Telegram channel for discussions | Buy me a coffee | GitHub Sponsors **IPTVnator** is a video player application that provides support for IPTV playlist playback (m3u, m3u8). The application allows users to import playlists using remote URLs or by uploading files from the local file system. Additionally, it supports EPG information in XMLTV format which can be provided via URL. The application is a cross-platform, open-source project built with Electron and Angular. ‚ö†Ô∏è Note: IPTVnator does not provide any playlists or other digital content. The channels and pictures in the screenshots are for demonstration purposes only. ![IPTVnator: Channels list, player and epg list](./iptv-dark-theme.png) ## Features - M3u and M3u8 playlist support üì∫ - Xtream Code (XC) and Stalker portal (STB) support - External player support - MPV, VLC - Add playlists from the file system or remote URLs üìÇ - Automatic playlist updates on application startup - Channel search functionality üîç - EPG support (TV Guide) with detailed information - TV archive/catchup/timeshift functionality - Group-based channel list - Favorite channels management - Global favorites aggregated from all playlists - HTML video player with HLS.js support or Video.js-based player - Internationalization with support for 16 languages: * Arabic * Moroccan arabic * English * Russian * German * Korean * Spanish * Chinese * Traditional chinese * French * Italian * Turkish * Japanese * Dutch * Belarusian * Polish - Custom "User Agent" header configuration for playlists - Light and Dark themes - Docker version available for self-hosting ## Screenshots: | Welcome screen: Playlists overview | Main player interface with channels sidebar and video player | | :----------------------------------------------------------------: | :-----------------------------------------------------------: | | ![Welcome screen: Playlists overview](./playlists.png) | ![Sidebar with channel and video player](./iptv-main.png) | | Welcome screen: Add playlist via file upload | Welcome screen: Add playlist via URL | | ![Welcome screen: Add playlist via file upload](./iptv-upload.png) | ![Welcome screen: Add playlist via URL](./upload-via-url.png) | | EPG Sidebar: TV guide on the right side | General application settings | | ![EPG: TV guide on the right side](./iptv-epg.png) | ![General app settings](./iptv-settings.png) | | Playlist settings | | ![Playlist settings](./iptv-playlist-settings.png) | | _Note: First version of the application which was developed as a PWA is available in an extra git branch._ ## Download Download the latest version of the application for macOS, Windows, and Linux from the [release page](https://github.com/4gray/iptvnator/releases). Alternatively, you can install the application using one of the following package managers: ### Homebrew ```shell $ brew install iptvnator ``` ### Snap ```shell $ sudo snap install iptvnator ``` ### Arch Also available as an Arch PKG, [iptvnator-bin](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/iptvnator-bin/), in the AUR (using your favourite AUR-helper, .e.g. `yay`) ```shell $ yay -S iptvnator-bin ``` ### Gentoo You can install IPTVnator from the [gentoo-zh overlay](https://github.com/microcai/gentoo-zh) ```shell sudo eselect repository enable gentoo-zh sudo emerge --sync gentoo-zh sudo emerge iptvnator-bin ``` [![Get it from the Snap Store](https://snapcraft.io/static/images/badges/en/snap-store-black.svg)](https://snapcraft.io/iptvnator) ## Troubleshooting ### macOS: "App is damaged and can't be opened" Due to Apple's Gatekeeper security and code signing requirements, you may need to remove the quarantine flag from the downloaded application: ```bash xattr -c /Applications/IPTVnator.app ``` Alternatively, if the app is located in a different directory: ```bash xattr -c ~/Downloads/IPTVnator.app ``` ### Linux: chrome-sandbox Issues If you encounter the following error when launching IPTVnator: ``` The SUID sandbox helper binary was found, but is not configured correctly. Rather than run without sandboxing I'm aborting now. You need to make sure that chrome-sandbox is owned by root and has mode 4755. ``` **Solution 1: Fix chrome-sandbox permissions (Recommended for .deb/.rpm installations)** Navigate to the IPTVnator installation directory and run: ```bash sudo chown root:root chrome-sandbox sudo chmod 4755 chrome-sandbox ``` **Solution 2: Launch with --no-sandbox flag** Edit the desktop launcher file to add the `--no-sandbox` flag: 1. Find your desktop file location: - **Ubuntu/Debian**: `~/.local/share/applications/iptvnator.desktop` - **System-wide**: `/usr/share/applications/iptvnator.desktop` 2. Edit the file and modify the `Exec` line: ``` Exec=iptvnator --no-sandbox %U ``` 3. Save the file and relaunch the application from your application menu. Alternatively, you can launch IPTVnator from the terminal with the flag: ```bash iptvnator --no-sandbox ``` ## How to Build and Develop Requirements: - Node.js with npm 1. Clone this repository and install project dependencies: ``` $ npm install ``` 2. Start the application: ``` $ npm run serve:backend ``` This will open the Electron app in a separate window, while the Angular dev server will run at http://localhost:4200. To run only the Angular app without Electron, use: ``` $ npm run serve:frontend ``` ## Disclaimer **IPTVnator doesn't provide any playlists or other digital content.** [![All Contributors](https://img.shields.io/badge/all_contributors-13-orange.svg?style=flat-square)](#contributors)

# IPTVnator - IPTV Player Application

Telegram channel for discussions | Buy me a coffee | GitHub Sponsors **IPTVnator** is a video player application that provides support for IPTV playlist playback (m3u, m3u8). The application allows users to import playlists using remote URLs or by uploading files from the local file system. Additionally, it supports EPG information in XMLTV format which can be provided via URL. The application is a cross-platform, open-source project built with Electron and Angular. ‚ö†Ô∏è Note: IPTVnator does not provide any playlists or other digital content. The channels and pictures in the screenshots are for demonstration purposes only. ![IPTVnator: Channels list, player and epg list](./iptv-dark-theme.png) ## Features - M3u and M3u8 playlist support üì∫ - Xtream Code (XC) and Stalker portal (STB) support - External player support - MPV, VLC - Add playlists from the file system or remote URLs üìÇ - Automatic playlist updates on application startup - Channel search functionality üîç - EPG support (TV Guide) with detailed information - TV archive/catchup/timeshift functionality - Group-based channel list - Favorite channels management - Global favorites aggregated from all playlists - HTML video player with HLS.js support or Video.js-based player - Internationalization with support for 16 languages: * Arabic * Moroccan arabic * English * Russian * German * Korean * Spanish * Chinese * Traditional chinese * French * Italian * Turkish * Japanese * Dutch * Belarusian * Polish - Custom "User Agent" header configuration for playlists - Light and Dark themes - Docker version available for self-hosting ## Screenshots: | Welcome screen: Playlists overview | Main player interface with channels sidebar and video player | | :----------------------------------------------------------------: | :-----------------------------------------------------------: | | ![Welcome screen: Playlists overview](./playlists.png) | ![Sidebar with channel and video player](./iptv-main.png) | | Welcome screen: Add playlist via file upload | Welcome screen: Add playlist via URL | | ![Welcome screen: Add playlist via file upload](./iptv-upload.png) | ![Welcome screen: Add playlist via URL](./upload-via-url.png) | | EPG Sidebar: TV guide on the right side | General application settings | | ![EPG: TV guide on the right side](./iptv-epg.png) | ![General app settings](./iptv-settings.png) | | Playlist settings | | ![Playlist settings](./iptv-playlist-settings.png) | | _Note: First version of the application which was developed as a PWA is available in an extra git branch._ ## Download Download the latest version of the application for macOS, Windows, and Linux from the [release page](https://github.com/4gray/iptvnator/releases). Alternatively, you can install the application using one of the following package managers: ### Homebrew ```shell $ brew install iptvnator ``` ### Snap ```shell $ sudo snap install iptvnator ``` ### Arch Also available as an Arch PKG, [iptvnator-bin](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/iptvnator-bin/), in the AUR (using your favourite AUR-helper, .e.g. `yay`) ```shell $ yay -S iptvnator-bin ``` ### Gentoo You can install IPTVnator from the [gentoo-zh overlay](https://github.com/microcai/gentoo-zh) ```shell sudo eselect repository enable gentoo-zh sudo emerge --sync gentoo-zh sudo emerge iptvnator-bin ``` [![Get it from the Snap Store](https://snapcraft.io/static/images/badges/en/snap-store-black.svg)](https://snapcraft.io/iptvnator) ## Troubleshooting ### macOS: "App is damaged and can't be opened" Due to Apple's Gatekeeper security and code signing requirements, you may need to remove the quarantine flag from the downloaded application: ```bash xattr -c /Applications/IPTVnator.app ``` Alternatively, if the app is located in a different directory: ```bash xattr -c ~/Downloads/IPTVnator.app ``` ### Linux: chrome-sandbox Issues If you encounter the following error when launching IPTVnator: ``` The SUID sandbox helper binary was found, but is not configured correctly. Rather than run without sandboxing I'm aborting now. You need to make sure that chrome-sandbox is owned by root and has mode 4755. ``` **Solution 1: Fix chrome-sandbox permissions (Recommended for .deb/.rpm installations)** Navigate to the IPTVnator installation directory and run: ```bash sudo chown root:root chrome-sandbox sudo chmod 4755 chrome-sandbox ``` **Solution 2: Launch with --no-sandbox flag** Edit the desktop launcher file to add the `--no-sandbox` flag: 1. Find your desktop file location: - **Ubuntu/Debian**: `~/.local/share/applications/iptvnator.desktop` - **System-wide**: `/usr/share/applications/iptvnator.desktop` 2. Edit the file and modify the `Exec` line: ``` Exec=iptvnator --no-sandbox %U ``` 3. Save the file and relaunch the application from your application menu. Alternatively, you can launch IPTVnator from the terminal with the flag: ```bash iptvnator --no-sandbox ``` ## How to Build and Develop Requirements: - Node.js with npm 1. Clone this repository and install project dependencies: ``` $ npm install ``` 2. Start the application: ``` $ npm run serve:backend ``` This will open the Electron app in a separate window, while the Angular dev server will run at http://localhost:4200. To run only the Angular app without Electron, use: ``` $ npm run serve:frontend ``` ## Disclaimer **IPTVnator doesn't provide any playlists or other digital content.** [![All Contributors](https://img.shields.io/badge/all_contributors-13-orange.svg?style=flat-square)](#contributors)

content.text: Done! I've added the website link at the top of the README, right before the Telegram and donation links. The website link now appears prominently with a globe emoji (üåê) for visual distinction.
